title: Boundaries & Respect
description: Explore how you navigate boundaries and respect in your intimate life.

questions.text: When it comes to setting intimate boundaries, I find it...
choices: Natural—I know what I'm comfortable with
Sometimes difficult—I don't want to disappoint
Important but vulnerable
An ongoing process as I learn about myself

therapeutic.rationale: Boundary-setting ease varies. Natural-setters are clear; people-pleasers struggle with disappointing; vulnerable-feelers find it hard but necessary; learners are discovering. Your partner can't respect boundaries they don't know about.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The natural-setter may not understand why their partner struggles; the people-pleaser may need more safety to be honest. Create space for boundary conversations.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ease with boundaries makes intimate communication flow more smoothly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How easy or hard is it for you to set boundaries? What makes it easier?

questions.text: I want my partner to respond to my boundaries by...
choices: Respecting them without question
Understanding why they matter to me
Checking in gently if they want to understand more
Simply accepting and moving on

therapeutic.rationale: Preferred boundary responses vary. Respect-without-question types want immediate acceptance; understanding-seekers want to be known; check-in types welcome gentle curiosity; move-on types don't want to dwell. Knowing your partner's preference helps you respond well.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different preferences are fine—the key is that boundaries are ultimately respected. Some questions for understanding are okay; pressure to change is not.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response preference creates predictability around boundary conversations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you want your partner to respond when you set a boundary? What would feel supportive?

questions.text: Boundaries in intimacy, to me, are...
choices: Non-negotiable—they define what's okay for me
Important but sometimes flexible with trust
Something I'm still figuring out
Subject to evolve as we grow together

therapeutic.rationale: Views on boundaries vary. Non-negotiable types have firm limits; flexible-with-trust types bend with safety; figuring-out types are discovering; evolvers see change as natural. All views are valid—the key is consent.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different views are fine—what matters is that both partners' limits are respected in the moment. Even flexible boundaries can have firm moments.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared boundary philosophy creates aligned expectations about how limits work.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you think about your intimate boundaries? Are they firm or flexible? Why?

questions.text: If I ever felt my boundaries weren't being respected, I'd want to...
choices: Address it directly in the moment
Talk about it afterward when calm
Trust my partner to check in with me
Have an established safe word or signal

therapeutic.rationale: Boundary protection preferences vary. Direct-addressers speak up immediately; afterward-talkers process later; trust-checkers want partner initiation; signal-users want non-verbal options. Having a plan before it's needed creates safety.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Multiple approaches can coexist. Having both a safe word AND the ability to talk afterward covers more ground.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared preference creates a clear plan for how to handle boundary moments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would you do if you felt a boundary wasn't being respected? Do you have a plan?

questions.text: The foundation of respect in our intimate life should be...
choices: Ongoing, enthusiastic consent
Knowing each other deeply over time
Never assuming—always checking in
Trust built through consistent care

therapeutic.rationale: Respect foundations vary but all lead to consent. Ongoing-consent types check continuously; knowers build deep understanding; never-assumers verify; trust-builders rely on patterns. All can coexist in healthy relationships.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these foundations support each other. Emphasize different aspects without abandoning the core of consent.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared foundation philosophy aligns your approach to respect in intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does respect look like in your intimate life? How do you want it to feel?
